item.title: Damaris Zurell - Curriculum vitae
item.description: Contact - Education - Career - Projects - Awards - Professional activities - Memberships I am a professor of Ecology and Macroecology at the University of Potsdam, with a deep interest in how biodiversity responds to environmental change. My work bridges theoretical ecology, conservation science, and predictive biodiversity modelling, often connecting basic research with real-world conservation challenges. I lead an interdisciplinary research group, coordinate international initiatives, and actively contribute to global scientific networks on biodiversity and climate change.

item.title: Join the lab
Open thesis topics
item.description: Intra-specific variation in dispersal: a simulation approach (Master thesis) Dynamic occupancy modelling of Swiss breeding birds (Master thesis) Climate change-induced niche shifts in North American birds (Master thesis) Climatic niche asymmetry in plants of the Americas (Master thesis) Intra-specific variation in dispersal: a simulation approach (Master thesis) Dispersal is a central biological process determining the movement and genetic exchange between populations, and the range dynamics of species under global change.

item.title: Downloads
item.description: You can download some of my codes from my github site. Repository IBM_OptimalForaging C++ codes for individual-based foraging model described in Zurell et al. (2015) Oikos. Repository Rcodes_MapNovelEnvironments_SDMs R codes for mapping novel environments (SDM inflated response curves and environmental overlap masks) described in Zurell et al. (2012) DDI.
